Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Analytical Transmission Electron Microscope with Cryogenic Imaging Capabilites for Research and Teaching at a PUI
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Hemali Rathnayake from Western Kentucky University and colleagues Shivendra Sahi, Muhammad Jahan, Rajalingam Dakshinanurthy and Rodney King will acquire an analytical transmission electron microscope (TEM) with cryogenic imaging capabilites. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) organic-inorganic nanostructures as energy harvesting materials for green energy technology; (b) synthesis and characterization gold nanoparticles for antimicrobial applications; (c) genome discovery and exploration; (d) in plant-mediated biosynthesis of gold and silver nanoparticles; (e) nanomachining and characterization of thin films; (f) carbon nanotubes and clays; and (g) modified natural minerals for water treatment.

In a transmission electron microscope (TEM) a beam of electrons is transmitted through a very thin sample. These electrons interact with the material as it passes through and then an image is formed from such interaction which is then enlarged and focused onto an imaging device, e.g., a camera. This technique is capable of providing direct information on the local structure rather than the average structure determined by other techniques such as X-ray or neutron diffraction analysis. TEM has become an important research tool in the life, physical, material, and environmental sciences. Some examples are the study of complex systems such as tissue, polymers, gels, multi metal oxides, and others. The instrumentation will be used in research activities and also for research training and education of a large number of students from diverse backgrounds.

Project Overview:

This NSF-MRI award supported for an acquisition of a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) for undergraduate research and teaching at Western Kentucky University. The acquired TEM features a high-resolution objective lens, a cryostage, and a cryospecimen preparation and transfer system. This new microscope replaced our aged TEM, which after 33 years was both obsolete and became increasingly difficult to repair. The grant impacted to not only replace, but also expanded our TEM capabilities to better serve our students and faculty.

Intellectual Merit:

Transmission electron microscopes provide the best means for imaging particles with at least one dimension smaller than fifty nanometers.  After the acquisition of a new scope with enhanced resolution, digital imaging, and the ability to look at vitrified samples significantly has been expanded its utility for both faculty and students.

Research projects supported by the new TEM span a broad spectrum of research fields ranging from bionanotechnology and nanomaterials to polymer science.  Current research projects use the TEM to characterize the size and shape of inorganic nanoparticles, bacteriophages, synthetic nanoparticles, and inorganic microstructures like zeolites and when appropriate, to localize them within biological systems. Example of current research projects include characterization and localization of gold nanoparticles produced in living plants, evaluation antimicrobial properties of particles conjugated to antibodies, and characterization of other synthetic nanoparticles, inorganic nanostructures, natural nanoparticles, and bacteriophages. In all of these projects, isolated particles are observed in solvent free environment.  In some cases, drying samples could encounter many problems including particle aggregation and distortion. The acquisition of a cryostage with the new TEM  enabled to image particles in a frozen, vitrified solution without loss due to incomplete absorption or distortion due to drying. Additionally, existing undergraduate and graduate courses have been enhanced by the new TEM.  

Project Outcomes and Findings:

Summary:

Over three-year project period, the transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used for a total of 2,097 hours from July 15, 2014 to September 30, 2016 for research, educational training in course curricula, and community outreach.  64 students and staff were trained to use the TEM independently. From these 64 students,  3 were Hispanic (Sara Botero, Paula Stepp, and Marina Rolon) and 4 were African or African American (Jauan Burbage, Danielle Chavis, Amelia Smith, and Oluwadamilola Filani) Also among them, 4 Gatton students, 46 undergraduates, 11 graduates and 3 staff were trained on the instrument. Additional 390 students used the TEM for at least 20 minutes each with assistance as part of the Genome Discovery and Exploration Program (GDEP) courses or for research  and as  a part of students tours.  In addition 16 college professors observed the TEM as part of the "Small Genome Discovery workshop”. 

Broader Impact

During the three-year project period, the TEM met the needs of more that 12 faculty in chemistry, biology, physics, geology, and architectural & manufacturing sciences.  The research programs of each of these disciplines contributed novel findings to the broader range of scientific community in the form of journal publications (5) and conference presentations (100). Through the GENOM program 52 mycobacteriophages were identified and isolated during the three -year project period.

The growth of undergraduate education provided through BIOL 275, BIOL 322 and BIOL 404 has made a direct contribution to the development of students’ training in principal disciplines of science, engineering, and technology. As evidenced by number of students (total of 454) trained on the instrument as a part of the course curricula, the new microscope made a direct impact on the educational training program for undergraduate students at WKU and three other surrounding colleges. The growth of student body on the educational training program during the project period reflects the impact on development of the principal disciplines in STEM field.

 Impact on the development of human resources

Having a modern TEM has significantly helped our effort to train a technologically advanced workforce for our region, and ultimately help in its economic development. Clearly, the interdisciplinary research and educational programs has not only provided opportunities for undergraduate students and underrepresented minority students in south central Kentucky, but also there are broader impacts on the workforce development due to our location—at the edge of Appalachia.  Many of the students trained are still the first in their families to attend college, coming from rural counties with limited opportunities. Having hands-on-experience on such high-tech equipment for these students is a dream come true during their academic life. The training has improved students’ retention in research and their access to related professions in STEM field. During the three-year project period,  traditional undergraduates, junior high school students,graduate students, postdoctoral/staff research associates, and college professors were trained and prepared for their future professional careers in a STEM disciplines. Moreover, the educational training program has provided exposure for middle and high school students through VAMPY and SCATS summer programs.
